body_text.text: Convention. Renaissance Denver Hotel, Denver, Colorado. June 15-18. The American Horse Council convention provides a forum where industry leaders, horse owners and enthusiasts meet to share ideas and information. It is the place where issues important to the well-being of our horses and our industry are discussed by all who attend. A partial listing of topics: 9 New social ethic for animals in the equine industry. Dr. Bernard Rollin 9 The changing nature of animal health emergencies and the role of owners and practitioners in animal health emergency management. Rob Werge, Dr. Joe Annelli, Dr. Jerry Bohlender Registration fees: before May 30, AHC members $200, non-members $250; after May 30, AHC members $240, non-members $300. Add $100 for spouses to each category. Daily registration ranges from $50 to $200, depending on which day, and whether member or non-member. For more information, contact: American Horse Council, 1700 K St., Ste. 300, Washington, DC 20006; phone (202) This 31/2 day shortcourse contains lectures over such topics as anatomy and endocrinology of the mare and stallion, management of problem mares, control of the estrous cycle, gestation and foaling, feeding the broodmare and young horse, record-keeping, ultrasonography and embryo transfer. A hands-on laboratory is also included. This shortcourse is designed for mare and stallion owners and managers who want to learn the most modern and efficient methods for enhancing the success of their breeding programs. For more information and registration applications, contact: Dr. Martha M. Vogelsang at (409) 845-7731. Enrollment is limited to 16 and the shortcourses tend to fill quickly.
Continued from page 230 the Future'. Cambridge, England. July 7-10.

The symposium will provide an international forum for the exchange of information. The comprehensive program will feature breeding technology, the role of the Thoroughbred in the world performance horse industry and a timely review of stress in performance horses using the experience of the 1996 Olympics. Program will include: 9 World performance horse industry. 9 Improving genetic potential. 9 The influence of the Thoroughbred on sport horse breeding. 9 Modern breeding technologies. 9 Exploiting improvement -horse selection, sales, etc. 9 Stress -do improved horses need better management to avoid stress? 9 Travel and health. 9 Recent advances in equine nutrition. 9 Training -especially what can be learned from National Hunt racing. 9 Marketing the sport, making sponsorship work. For more information, contact: Karen Pearson, Royal Agricultural Society of England, 01203 696969; FAX 01023 696900.

Convention. Reno-Sparks Convention Center, Reno, Nevada. July 21-24. Monday, July 21 9 Overview of equine dental examination and pathophysiology. James Schumacher 9 Management of equine dental disease, a case-based approach. James Schumacher 9 Clinical evaluation of weight loss in the horse. Kathy Yvorchuk 9 Case-based approach to the evaluation of the equine neonate. Kathy Yvorchuk Tuesday, July 22 9 Nutrition for the growing horse. Sarah L. Ralston 9 Nutrition for the clinically ill horse. Sarah L. Ralston 9 Nutrition for the performance horse. Craig Thatcher 9 Nutrition for the breeding stallion. Craig Thatcher Wednesday, July 23 9 Update on the current theories: pathogenesis of osteochondrosis. James LilUch 9 Diagnosis, treatment and prognosis of commonly occurring osteochondrosis lesions. James Lillich 9 Understanding and developing strategies for palmer heel pain in horses. Tracy A. This program will consist of lectu re and slide demonstration on anatomy and physiology of the mouth, including examination of the mastication process, procedures for floating teeth, removing wolf teeth, removing retained deciduous premolars, creating bit seats, treating malocclusion and abnormal wear, hook removal, dental extraction, incisor realignment, leveling teeth, cutting teeth, and the use of power tools. There will also be a lecture and slide demonstration on bitting the horse.

All prices include lunch, coffeebreaks, happy hour after the last session and proceedings as well as free access to the day program of Jumping Indoor Maastricht and the international trade exhibition of MICEM. TABREF1.text: Current therapy for laminitis in the horse. Tracy A. Turner it; WEB http:// www.finsystem.it/weva97 The 11th Annual Conference on Equine Dentistry. Concordville, Pennsylvania. September 11-13. Presented by International Association of Equine Dental Technicians. For more information, contact: IAEDT, PO Box 6095, Wilmington, DE 19804; or phone (703) 771-8158. 36th Annual Congress of the British Equine Veterinary Association. Harrogate, Yorkshire. September 17-20. For more information, contact: Miss S. G. Majendle, 5 Finlay St., London; phone 44-171-610-6080; FAX 44-171-610-6823. Diagnosis andTreatment of Lameness in the Horse. Colorado State University CVM, Fort Collins, Colorado. September 24-26. Instructors include: Dr. Ted Stashak, Dr. Wayne Mcllwraith, Dr. Gayle Trotter, Dr. Richard Park, Dr. Gary Baxter and Dr. Dean Hendrickson. This course will cover in detail the various causes and diagnosis of lameness in the horse. mail rschoono @ vag us,vth.colostate.edu; Web: www.vetmed.colostate.edu/clinsci/ce MEETINGS & NOTICES For more information, call: (888) 550-7862. Equine Respiratory and Neurological Disease. Dan Evans Memorial Equine Conference. San Luis Rey Downs, Bonsall, California. September 27-28. Presenters will include Dr. Steve Reed, Dr. Norm Rantanen, Dr. Joe Cannon, Dr. Barrie Grant and Mr. Brock Dumont. For more information, contact: Jay Rose, The Piedra Foundation, 4211 Holly Lane, Bonsall, CA 92003; phone & FAX (619) 726-9206; E-mail tpf@piedra.org; WEB http:// www.piedra.org.tpf Speakers will include Alan J. Ruggles, The Ohio State University, USA, Riitta-Mari Tulamo, Helsinki University, Finland, and Wendy Vaala, Mid-Atlantic Equine Clinic, New Jersey, USA. Special registration fee for non-Italian delegates. For further information, contact: Miss Ludovica Bellingeri, SIVE Secretary, SCIVAC Study Center, Via Trecchi, 20, 26100 Cremona, Italy; phone +39-372-460440; FAX +39-372-457091;e-mail info.scivac@softeam.it; WEB http:// www.softeam.it/scivac October Equine Dentistry. Colorado State University CVM, Fort Collins, Colorado. October 1-3. Instructors include: Dr. D. G. Bennett, Dr. Patrick McCue, Dr. Leon Scrutchfield and Dr. Jack Easley.

TABREF2.text: mail rschoono @ vagus.vth.colostate.edu; Web www.vetmed.colostate.edu/clinsci/ce Wild West Veterinary Conference (WWVC). Reno Hilton Hotel, Reno, Nevada. October 6-10. The WWVC is a regional conference hosted by the Arizona, California, Nevada and Oregon Veterinary Medical Associations, and offers more than 300 hours of continuing education to choose from in the areas of small animal, equine, food animal/ large animal and exotics. For more information, call: (800) 331-5706. No registration fee for spouses or children. Low cost air fare available. A $100 pp deposit due at time of booking, with the balance due August 15. Fares include stateroom, all meals on board, entertainment and most on-board activities. For more information, contact: JEVS/Baja Cruise, PO Box 1209, Wildomar, CA 92595; phone (909) 678-1889; FAX (909) 678-1885; e-mail vetdata@inland.net Annual Equine Symposium: Neurology. Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas. October 25-26. For more information, contact: Office of Veterinary Continuing Education, Texas A&M University (409) 845-9102; FAX (409)862-2832. Colorado State University CVM, Fort Collins, Colorado. November 13-14. Instructors include: Dr. Dean Hendrickson, Dr. Kate Savage, and Dr. Josie Traub-Dargatz. The course will cover the basic uses of both flexible and rigid endoscopes in their uses for upper respiratory, lower respiratory, gastric, and urinary diseases, as well as abdominal and thoracic abnormalities. Registration fee: $500 for non-CVMA members, and $450 for CVMA members. Course is limited, so register early. For more information, contact: Colorado State University, College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Fort Collins, CO 80523; phone (800) 457-9715 or (970) 491-1274; FAX (970) 491-1274; e-mail rschoono @vagus.vth.colostate.edu; Web www.vetmed.colostate.edu/clinsci/ce 2nd Arab International Equine Exhibition for Horse and Equipment. Dubai World Trade Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates. November 23-26. The Exhibition brings together under one roof the best of equestrian equipment, products and accessories and the people who use them. This high profile exhibition will attract livestock, leading breeders, internationally renowned trainers, bloodstock agents, livery yards, riding schools, saddlers and farriers. For more information, contact: AI Fajer, Information & Services, P.O. Box 11183, Dubai, U.A.E.; phone 971 4 621133; FAX 971 4 622802. Management of the Acute Abdomen in the Horse. Colorado State University CVM, Fort Collins, Colorado. December 3-5. Instructors include: Dr. Ted Stashak, Dr. Gayle Trotter, Dr. Josie Traub-Dargatz, Dr. Kate Savage, Dr. Gary Baxter, Dr. Dean Hendrickson and Dr. Ann Wagner. The clinical evaluation of the acute abdominal patient will be reviewed. Medical and surgical therapy will be discussed with specific emphasis on selection of drugs, preoperative patient preparation, anesthesia, intraoperative findings, postoperative care and complications. Registration fee: $600 for non-CVMA members, and $540 for CVMA members. Course is limited, so register early. For more information, contact: Colorado State University, College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, Fort Collins, CO 80523; phone (800) 457-9715 or (970) 491-1274; FAX (970) 491-1274; email rschoono @ vagus.vth.colostate.edu; Web www.vetmed.colostate.edu/clinsci/ce 43rd Annual Convention The American Association of Equine Practitioners. Phoenix Civic Plaza, Phoenix, Arizona. December 7-1 O. For more information contact AAEP, 4075 Iron Works Pike, Lexington, KY 40511. Phone (600) 443-0177 or (606) 233-0147; Fax (606) 233-1968.
